title: Doctors are trialing whether sleeping pill Belsomra could help alcoholics curb their addiction
text:
An insomnia drug could also be used to prevent recovering alcoholics from relapsing, doctors believe.

Australian researchers will give suvorexant (Belsomra) to 128 recovering alcoholics who also struggle to sleep as a result of their addiction.

Experts at The Florey Institute and St Vincent’s Hospital in Melbourne hope curing alcoholics' insomnia could have a knock-on effect on their drinking habit.

Chronic drinking starves the body of essential REM sleep, thought to be the most deeply restful phase.

Researchers suspect tiredness boosts activity in brain regions related to addiction and craving more alcohol.

Alcoholics can also become trapped in a vicious cycle where consuming alcohol is the only way they can drift off.

Sleeping pill Belsomra is being trialled on 128 alcoholics to see if it can treat their addiction (file)

Chronic drinking starves the body of essential REM sleep, thought to be the most deeply restful phase

Suvorexant, sold under the brand name Belsomra, has become the go-to sleeping pill for Americans after it was approved by the FDA in 2015.

It is estimated that more than 4,000 prescriptions are written a week by doctors in the US.

The drug is still being trialled in the UK for insomnia, but the most recent study in 2016 found it showed 'improvements in some sleep parametres'.

But it also caused some adverse effects including daytime drowsiness and abnormal dreams. The NHS watchdog NICE is still considering whether to roll it out in the UK.

Led by Andrew Lawrence, a professor in neuroscience and addiction, the new trial will see participants receive either Belsomra or placebo treatment daily for seven to ten days in hospital.

They will then continue their treatment for up to six months at home with regular follow-ups.

The study will examine sleep measures in trial participants, as well as looking at alcohol withdrawal symptoms and ongoing alcohol use.

Belsomra is thought to block the binding of a series of amino acids in parts of the brain involved in addiction, known as the orexin system.

The medication also targets the amygdala, a brain region associated with mood disorders, including depression and anxiety - which also cause people to drink.

Professor Lawrence said: 'The orexin system demonstrates just how complicated addiction can be.

'We know that the chronic intake of alcohol greatly disrupts sleep and wake patterns which, in turn, can drive the brain to further seek and consume alcohol.

'Over 155,000 Australians are hospitalised each year from alcohol use disorder.

'Yet despite the significant social and economic burden of this disease, no new treatments have been approved in Australia in over two decades.'
description: Scientists from The Florey Institute and St Vincent's Hospital in Melbourne, Australia, will give the sleeping pill to 128 alcoholics over six months. They believe tiredness causes alcohol cravings.
authors: Connor Boyd Health Reporter For Mailonline
